headline: CNN News Central
subHeadline: John Martin is Interviewed about Possibly Solving a 44-Year-Old Mystery; Majority of Influencers Don't Check Accuracy; CNN Hosts Thanksgiving in America. Aired 9:30-10a ET

utterances.speaker: JOHN BERMAN, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: All right, this morning, a stunning discovery in a Georgia pond may finally solve a 44 year old mystery.In 1980, Charles and Catherine Romer were driving back to New York from Florida when they vanished. All right, so recently this non- profit called Sunshine State Sonar alerted authorities who ultimately drained a pond along the route that they would have been traveling. And they found human remains inside a 1979 Lincoln Continental. The same model car that the Romers owned. With us now is John Martin, co-founder of the Sunshine State Sonar Team. All right, John, so, look, how did you find the car? JOHN MARTIN, CO-FOUNDER, SUNSHINE STATE SONAR TEAM: Well, we were - actually, there was another sonar team that had gone out to - to this body of water. And sonared the, you know, this body and came up with a vehicle and sent an image to my brother. And my brother looked over the image. They had concluded, after sonaring it, that it was a white pickup truck. After finding out the location of the - this white pickup truck, we were concerned and made a trip down there to do our own search of that body of water.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: And then -

utterances.speaker: MARTIN
utterances.sentences: And after conducting our -

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: I was just going to say, what did you find and what evidence was there?

utterances.speaker: MARTIN
utterances.sentences: Yes, and after doing - OK, so we conducted our own sonar search of the body of water and we came around the pond to a diner that had been there for years. And we got a hit on sonar of a vehicle right in front of the diner parking lot.And then we continued to search the pond and found the other vehicle that the other sonar team had - had discovered as well. So, there were two vehicles in that pond.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: And one of them was this Lincoln Continental.So - so what happens next after you find it?

utterances.speaker: MARTIN
utterances.sentences: After we find it, we suit up. We dive the vehicle. There was zero visibility in the lake, so everything was by feel. We started pulling parts from the vehicle to try to identify what kind of vehicle it was. My brother was - my brother Mike was able to pull the grill off of the vehicle. We brought it to the surface, brought it onshore, ran the part number on - on the grill and, sure enough, it came back to a Lincoln Continental.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: And -

utterances.speaker: MARTIN
utterances.sentences: And after doing that, I went back down and drove the vehicle and found an open window. I reached inside the window and just started feeling around. I felt something, you know, hard and long. So, I grabbed what I, you know, whatever it was, brought it to the surface of the water and, sure enough, it happened to be a femur bone. So, we knew right then and there we had remains in the vehicle.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: A human bone.

utterances.speaker: MARTIN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: Has anyone told you whether or not the DNA results have come back on that?

utterances.speaker: MARTIN
utterances.sentences: No, that usually takes time just from experience on other cases we've solved. That takes time to get DNA back.

utterances.speaker: MARTIN
utterances.sentences: Actually, we were not working on this case. The other sonar team, which is run by a man named Jason, he's the one that alerted us to it, because when we had found out the location of this body of water, which was directly in front of the hotel, it concerned us. So, we made the trip down there to, you know, verify the vehicle that he had found and to sonar the rest of that body of water to see if we could find anything. And we just happened to find that - the Lincoln.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: So, the Lincoln, presumably, if it is the Lincoln, had been underwater for 44 years.

utterances.speaker: MARTIN
utterances.sentences: That's correct.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: You know, what condition was it in and how does that complicate what you're doing?

utterances.speaker: MARTIN
utterances.sentences: The condition of the vehicle was - I mean it wasn't too bad for being down there 44 years, but it was - it was pretty much deteriorated. You know, the parts came off pretty easy, as we - you know, as we were trying to pull parts off the vehicle, they were coming off pretty easy. But, you know, the law enforcement tried to retrieve the vehicle, andthey ended up pulling the rear axle off, which, part of the trunk came off with the rear axle, and they were a lot - they were able to grab a lot of evidence, a lot of personal items off of that little piece that they pulled out. And then they stopped trying to retrieve the vehicle and decided to drain the pond so that, you know, they could get all the evidence without losing it trying to pull the vehicle out.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: Well, John Martin, you and your team, just amazing work. And you and the rest of us waiting for those DNA results for a conclusive proof here.Thank you so much for being with us this morning. Have a Happy Thanksgiving.

utterances.speaker: MARTIN
utterances.sentences: You too.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: Aa majority of social media influencers are not checking the accuracy of the content that they are putting out. That's the big take and one - one of the takes and a really big warning coming from a new report from UNESCO, a division of the United Nations. With nearly 40 percent of young people saying they rely on influencers to get their news, well, that's a problem.CNN's Clare Duffy is looking into this. She's here with us now. What more are you learning about this, Clare?

utterances.speaker: CLARE DUFFY, CNN BUSINESS WRITER
utterances.sentences: Yes, Kate, we hate to see this after we know we talked so much about how influencers played such a huge role ahead of the election. We know that more than half of Americans are regularly getting news from social media. And it's a good reminder that although influencers often build these personal feeling relationships, they build brands around their trustworthiness. You really can't trust everything you see on social media.According to this report, 62 percent of influencers do not check the credibility of the information they're sharing before they share it to their followers. And here's how the report found that influencers are trying to gauge credibility. Forty percent of the respondents said they looked at measures of popularity, like the number of likes on a post to decide if it was credible before sharing it, which we know is not a great measure -

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: At all.

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: Because a lot of times it's the inflammatory content that is what goes viral. BOLDUAN

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: Twenty percent say they look to trusted friends and experts, so maybe a bit better. But just 17 percent said they actually looked at documentation and evidence to decide if something was trustworthy.We also know that influencers are often paid to promote content. Fifty-three percent of the respondents said that they had created sponsored content, but 7 percent of them said they presented that content as if it were unsponsored. So, while people may think they're getting this trustworthy information from people they rely on, actually they could be getting something that is biased or just plainly untrue. And, of course, we've seen this happen. We know one of the big prominent examples recently where these viral, false claims that immigrants in Ohio were stealing and eating peoples pets, amplified, of course, by President Donald Trump. And that ended up being really harmful. So, a good reminder to people to think critically about what they're seeing on social media.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: News literacy is something that needs to be taught in a very - in a much bigger way.These influencers are on platforms. These platforms are, you know, they know that they are being watched. They've been under scrutiny for forever for what the content that they've allowed on their platforms. Are the platforms doing anything in this regard?

utterances.speaker: DUFFY
utterances.sentences: Yes, I mean, of course the platforms say that they try to address misinformation. But we've actually seen a lot of these platforms pull back on their trust and safety and content moderation efforts on X. The platform says that it has these community notes that users can add to add context to claims. The other platforms will work with professional fact checkers. YouTube says that it doesn't allow videos with false claims about elections, for example, to be monetized, but they don't remove them. Meta also says that it doesn't promote content that's been labeled by fact checkers as false. But again, that's still up there. Many of these platforms say that they promote good information, but that doesn't always outweigh the false information that's out there.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: Just presenting - there's a big problem ahead, currently and ahead. And this is a great highlight to say that much more needs to be done.Thanks, Clare. Really appreciate it. So, how do astronauts in zero gravity celebrate Thanksgiving? I know this is something you woke up thinking today. We're going to show you the holiday menu on the - at the International Space Station. And the new additions to tomorrow's big Thanksgiving Day Parade will be joining us live. Alternate captain, can John Berman and Erica Hill handle the Thanksgiving trivia I just cooked up. [09:45:03] Stick around. You'll find out. (COMMERCIAL BREAK)

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: NASA astronauts, they get to celebrate the Thanksgiving holiday a couple hundred miles above earth. That includes Butch Williams - Butch Wilmore, I should say, and Suni Williams, who had their stay at the International Space Station extended because they got stuck there, frankly. They just floated this Thanksgiving message to everyone.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: We've got a container here of all the things that we're going to enjoy on Thanksgiving. It is a feast.Let me see, we've got brussel -

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: We've got sardines.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Brussel sprouts, butternut squash, apples and spice -

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Smoked turkey.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: And - and smoked turkey. It's going to be delicious.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: It's true we have much to be thankful for. On a professional stance, I mean there's not many places that you can be that you can actually lay on the ceiling. And this is one of them. We're thankful for zero gravity. It's fantastic.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: I mean, you love it. And if you can - you can lay on the ceiling just depending on how much you drink during dinner. But, you know, we'll get to that later.We also do have breaking news that we need to get to. Not breaking news. But breaking news. There's a new addition to the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade this year. Two additions, actually. And you are in luck. They are both here with us for their exclusive first live appearance together. John Berman and Erica Hill shepherding CNN's new and first "Thanksgiving in America" special.

utterances.speaker: ERICA HILL, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Yes. BOLDUAN

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: I baked for you guys this morning. I made some little egg bites. And these are great for you to have maybe Thanksgiving morning, or today, when you're watching the parade. They pair lovely with coffee and mimosa, perhaps a bloody maria, your choice.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: Did you prepare them at home before you came in or did -

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: I did. I did. I baked these last night for you. And they looked a little better when I brought them out of the oven. They got a little flat. But you've got - this one's got some ham in it. There's cheddar and jalapeno and then also a scallion.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: Oh, delicious.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: Delish. I love a scallion.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: I think it's full of protein as well.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: A scallion. The scallion is that one. Yes, full of protein.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: Full of protein. I am -

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: When you're ready for a protein bite, babe, there you go.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: Yes, going to - going to happen. I found the protein.JB, with your mouth full, what are we in store for tomorrow?

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: This is going to be the best Thanksgiving Parade special that CNN has ever done.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: Can confirm. Yes, will be.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: Single source approved.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: It's also the first -

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: Yes, exactly.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: CNN Thanksgiving Parade special that CNN has ever done.Look, we got it all. We have the parade here in New York, which will be taking place right behind us. We're going to be covering parades live in - in Philadelphia -

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: Chicago, Detroit, Houston.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: Houston. And wherever you are, if there's a parade, we'll be there.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: We can get there in a moment's notice. So, so tweet us.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: Sort of like Santa. We can get there right away.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: Right away, yes.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: We will find you.And what - this is more research than you do for literally anything.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: This is our - this is our Bible.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: We have worked together forever. John Berman's a genius and never has to prepare.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: This is my -

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: What is this?

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: This is my Thanksgiving briefing book, "Thanksgiving in America," prepared by - by Anna Glickman, who sits up there.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: The one and only.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: I haven't studied it yet. I'm going to spend all day today memorizing the facts here about Thanksgiving. So, this is - this is learning that we're going to do.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: We're going to be - we're going to be ready. There's a - there's a question about whether tomorrow. It could rain heavily here in New York.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: But I think that's also maybe, Berman, why we're on this assignment because we have some hurricane experience.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: That's right.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: And we both have giant bins full of rain gear. So, we're ready.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: I think the two main qualifications, when they were looking for hosts for the Thanksgiving special, number one, people who've covered hurricanes before. And, number two, people - the only two people who had already agreed to work Thanksgiving morning.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: That could be it, too.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: That could be it also.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: That is not true. It is because of your sparkling personality -

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: Bingo.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: And your ability to - to multitask and do amazing things, and your love of facts. We - no, no, no.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: We do love facts.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: I will say - OK, OK.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: What?

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: I was just going to say, I missed the celebrities. We have a lot of celebrities tomorrow too.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: Oh, we do have a lot of celebrities. We've got Bobby Flay, who's also in the family, so we love that, that he's with us.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: Our friends from "Inside the NBA." Who else is on our list?

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: The Temptations.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: The temptations.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: They're going to be singing.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: Andy Grammer.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: Oh, fun.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: It's huge. All right, I'm sorry, I didn't mean to interrupt.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: Now we're out of time, but not out of time.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: All right. (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: So, I thought, in this - this delicious day, you guys should do a little Thanksgiving trivia to prepare you for tomorrow.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: Oh, boy.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: OK.We'll run through these as quick as possible.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: This is like bringing back a lot of good memories for us.OK, who was the first president to pardon - oh, this is number one. Who was the first president to pardon a turkey?

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: I actually know this one.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: Shocker.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: Abraham Lincoln. BOLDUAN

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: It was Abraham Lincoln.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: Pardon a turkey. Yes.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: It was Abraham Lincoln.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: His son, Tad, had like a turkey somehow. And he wanted to pardon the turkey.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: We have a different answer, so we're going to have to go back and check that, because the answer I was - I received was that it was John F. Kennedy.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: I believe I saw that in our coverage of the turkey pardon earlier this week that it was, in fact, Lincoln. So, we're going to -

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: I'm going to blame the fact checker for that one.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: Yes. Yes. This is one of those social media influencer thing where, like -

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: Oh, sorry, I got that one from social media.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: Moving on. How many calories on average are consumed per person at Thanksgiving dinner?

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: Twenty-seven hundred.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: I'm going to say, yes, 2,700.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: Three thousand to four thousand.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: Whoa!

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: Oh, that's actually pretty close. OK.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: No, I was - I was going to be like one million.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: For one person?

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: That's a lot.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: That's a lot. All right.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: I mean you - you got to pound it.Which president refused to celebrate Thanksgiving, number five, refused to celebrate Thanksgiving as a national holiday?

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: Oh, that I don't' know. HILL

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: Calvin Coolidge.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: So close. No. Thomas Jefferson, so I'm told.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: Was it even really a thing at that point?

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: No, that's my concern. I actually don't - I don't think it was a thing with (INAUDIBLE) Abraham Lincoln.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: Stop trying to game the system.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: All right. All right. All right.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: Just go with it for God's sake.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: (INAUDIBLE) first over here. Us two.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: OK, this one, I don't even care if it's true, because I love it.Number seven, which president received a live raccoon as a Thanksgiving present?

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: Oh.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: A live raccoon.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: Let me go Teddy Roosevelt.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: No, but it was actually your other answer, Calvin Coolidge.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: Oh.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: It was Calvin.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: Calvin Coolidge.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: Why do you think that occurred is what I want to dig into.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: Silent cow. Also lover of raccoons.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: And they're really cute sometimes.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: How many pumpkin pies are consumed every Thanksgiving?

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: Oh, wow. A lot.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: Well, there's 350 million people. I'm going to go with 100 million.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: No. About 50 million. But a lot wins.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: That's still a lot.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: Erica won. Sorry, John. Keep working.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: Oh, I just heard that ding. Is that the ding of a correct answer?

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: Yes. Yes. Yes.

utterances.speaker: HILL
utterances.sentences: Lovely. I love it when we have sound effects.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: Do not forget, you can join CNN for the ultimate Thanksgiving morning watch party featuring, as we know, celebrity appearances, a live view of parades across the country, and, most importantly, this dynamic duo all morning long. It starts tomorrow at 8

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: All this information. A binder full of Thanksgiving information. A binders full of Thanksgiving information will all be here.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: You have binders full of Thanksgiving?

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: Along with egg bites. In my head.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: Thank you all for joining us. Have a wonderful, safe holiday, whatever you're doing, but make sure you're at a television at 8

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: You matter. What.
